title: New polyhydroxy sterols from the marine sponge Callyspongia fibrosa (Ridley and Dendly).
abstract:
noFour new polyhydroxylated sterols are isolated from Marine sponge Callyspongia fibrosa collected from\ud
the Gulf of Mannar, western Bay of Bengal (India). The structural assignment is based on 1H and 13C NMR\ud
spectra. All sterols are based on the known 24S-24-methyl cholesterol 1 which is also isolated, and contain\ud
3b,6b-dihydroxy system and 25-O-acetate as common features (except in the case of sterol 6 that has\ud
a D25 in the place of 25-OAc). Additional OH substitution is also present at 5a in 4a and at 8b in 5. A further\ud
12b-OH is present in 6 and 7. The hydroxylation pattern is so far known only in coral sterols but is\ud
without a precedent in sponge sterols. The major steroid 4a showed antimalarial activity against Plasmodium\ud
falciparum on the chloroquine-resistant stain better than on the chloroquine-sensitive strain

Callyspongia fibrosa</dc:subject><dc:description>
no</dc:description><dc:description>
Four new polyhydroxylated sterols are isolated from Marine sponge Callyspongia fibrosa collected from\ud
the Gulf of Mannar, western Bay of Bengal (India). The structural assignment is based on 1H and 13C NMR\ud
spectra. All sterols are based on the known 24S-24-methyl cholesterol 1 which is also isolated, and contain\ud
3b,6b-dihydroxy system and 25-O-acetate as common features (except in the case of sterol 6 that has\ud
a D25 in the place of 25-OAc). Additional OH substitution is also present at 5a in 4a and at 8b in 5. A further\ud
12b-OH is present in 6 and 7. The hydroxylation pattern is so far known only in coral sterols but is\ud
without a precedent in sponge sterols. The major steroid 4a showed antimalarial activity against Plasmodium\ud
falciparum on the chloroquine-resistant stain better than on the chloroquine-sensitive strain.</dc:description><dc:date>
